newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: REED-ELSEVIER SAYS MDL PRICE FAIR.
newsitem.headline: REED-ELSEVIER SAYS MDL PRICE FAIR.

text.p: Anglo-Dutch publishing group Reed-Elsevier said on Monday that the $32 per share it was offering for MDL Information Systems Inc of the United States was a fair price which reflected the value of the company.

The bid put a $320 million price tag on the information systems, data base and supporting services company. MDL in 1995-96 made a net profit of $11 million on turnover of $62 million. MDL shares closed at $17.25 each on Friday.
"I think $32 is the value to us for the company, and for others as well," said executive committee member Paul Vlek.
"This price is on the table after a lot of negotiation. Half a year ago the share price was $33. We think the company is worth it," Vlek said in a telephone interview.
Vlek said Reed-Elsevier saw definite synergies in the acquisition of MDL, which would help it in its strategy of increasing its activities in on-line publishing.

"There are definitely advantages in cost sales. We can use their information and systems to sell to our client base. We can use their client base, the pharmaceutical industries in the first place, to sell our information," he said.

"We are a content provider, they are a service provider and we are gaining a lot of experience in combining the two. We're doing that in our on-line Lexis-Nexis systems and we can do that in science combined with this company as well," said Vlek.

Science publishing is Reed-Elsevier's most profitable business with an operating margin of 41.8 percent in 1996. The company plans to launch its ScienceDirect electronic delivery platform for scientific journals by mid-1997.
